frontmatter.title: Vibrational energy harvesting using a Duffing oscillator

children.value:
%matplotlib widget
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from scipy.integrate import odeint
import pandas as pd
from math import pi, sin, cos
Vibrational energy harvesting using a Duffing oscillator
In order to display figures properly, please download these images from
And put it in your working directory along with this notebook. This tutorial is inspired by the PhD work of Thomas Huguet, in particular the article
. Download it and read it to better understand the context of this exercise.
is a one-degree-of-freedom oscillator which, unlike a harmonic oscillator, has a non-linearity in its stiffness function. In its most general form, its differential equation can be written as:
\ddot x + \delta \dot x + \alpha x  +  \beta x^3 = A \sin (\omega_d t)
children.html: x¨+δx˙+αx+βx3=Asin⁡(ωdt)\ddot x + \delta \dot x + \alpha x + \beta x^3 = A \sin (\omega_d t)x¨+δx˙+αx+βx3=Asin(ωd​t)
βx3\beta x^3βx3

children.value: term. In this tutorial, we are going to work on a Duffing oscillator used in a practical purpose to recover vibratory energy in order to power autonomous communicating sensors. We are going to use the

from the INSA Lyon and the University of Savoie Mont Blanc (defended in 2018).
In the context of his article

, the choice of a Duffing oscillator is justified by its ability to efficiently recover energy over a broader frequency band than an equivalent harmonic oscillator.
We will discuss some very interesting aspects of the Duffing oscillator, including:
Its ability to have several different solutions for the same excitation.
Its ability to respond chaotically in some cases.
The Duffing oscillator that we will model is mechanically bistable, it is realized using the principle described on the diagram below (from

A beam with a mass in its center is compressed to buckling.
It is then excited by means of a shaker which represents the vibrations present in the environment.
An electrical extraction circuit is present but will not be modeled in this tutorial to simplify your task.
The system has been manufactured and tested in the laboratory and is shown in the figure below (from
The differential equation associated with this system is as follows:

children.html: x¨+ω022(x2xw2−1)x+ω0Qx˙=Adsin⁡(ωdt)\ddot x + \dfrac{\omega_0^2}{2}\left(\dfrac{x^2}{x_{w}^2} - 1\right)x + \dfrac{\omega_0}{Q} \dot x = A_d \sin \left( \omega_d t \right)x¨+2ω02​​(xw2​x2​−1)x+Qω0​​x˙=Ad​sin(ωd​t)

w0 = 121.0  # radians per second
Q = 87.0  # dimensionless
fd = 50.0  # Hertz
wd = 2.0 * pi * fd
Ad = 2.5  # meters per second squared

children.value: Depending on your starting point, the trajectory may lead to a different steady state regime.

Interpret the graphs obtained. In particular, emphasize the differences between transient and steady-state conditions. Does the latter depend on the same frequency as the acceleration imposed on the system? Is there more than one steady state? If so, how can you identify them all?
Propose ways to extract information on the dynamic behavior of this system.

is a tool developed by Henri Poincaré to observe and analyze the behavior of an integral curve.
In the present case, we propose to look at a particular form of Poincaré section by plotting only the positions of the system in the phase space that correspond to whole excitation periods,

children.html: t=0. mod Tdt = 0. \mbox{ mod } Tdt=0. mod Td

children.value:
.
Think of a way to plot these points and put it in place.

# POINCARE SECTION
# xp = # COMPLETE
# dotx =  # COMPLETE

plt.figure()
# plt.scatter(xp/xw, dotxp/(xw*w0), marker="o", s = 5, color = "r", label = "Poincaré Section")
# plt.scatter(xp[-5:]/xw, dotxp[-5:]/(xw*w0), marker="o", s = 30, color = "b", label = "Attractors")
plt.grid()
# plt.legend()
plt.xlabel("Position $x/x_{w}$")
plt.ylabel("Speed, $\dot x / {\omega_d x_{w}}$")
plt.show()

children.value: At this point, you may have noticed that the Poincaré section indicates that the trajectory of the system in the phase plane is a convergence to one (or more) particular points called attractors. Change the values of

children.html: X0X_0X0​

children.value: and try to find different attractors.

X0 = np.array([-4.0 * xw, 3.0 * xw * w0])
X0 = np.array([-4.0 * xw, 5.0 * xw * w0])
X0 = np.array([-3.0 * xw, 4.0 * xw * w0])
X0 = np.array([-3.0 * xw, 5.0 * xw * w0])
X0 = np.array([-7.0 * xw, 20.0 * xw * w0])
: write down a list of the attractors that you have found, you will used them in the next part.
How do you explain that the Poincaré section seems to converge to several points in some cases? Feel free to consult
How can we classify the attractors?

In the previous section, you observed that the Poincaré sections in the phase plane converge to particular points called attractors. The trajectory of an attractor in the phase plane is called an orbit.Draw these trajectories for all the attractors you found.
Interpret how these orbits are assembled in layers.
We now propose to work with a different excitation frequency. In this case, you will observe that the Poincaré section does not always converge to a point, it can also converge to a surface called a
. Make this strange attractor obvious by drawing the Poincaré sections. What do you observe ?
